answers: yoga [accept Hatha yoga; accept Yoga sutras of Patanjali; do NOT accept or prompt on “sutras”]
the Bhagavad Gita [do NOT accept or prompt on “Mahabharata”]
jnana (gya-ni or gyan) yoga < Ethan Ashbrook | Religion >
parts: Name this group of practices closely related with meditation and physical exercise. The modern Western form of this practice is adapted from the Hatha variant which focuses on asanas or body postures.
This text refers to yogic paths of salvation that include Karma and Bhakti. This 700-verse scripture begins as a conversation between a Pandava prince and his charioteer.
Karma and Bhakti Yoga are two of the three paths to spiritual liberation mentioned in the Bhagavad Gita. This path of knowledge is the third.

answers: pressure flow hypothesis/model [or Ernst Munch’s (pressure flow) hypothesis/model]
phloem
sieve tube elements [accept sieve tube members; accept sieve cells] < Michael Etzkorn | Biology >
parts: Name this hypothesis proposed by a German scientist. This hypothesis describes how an osmotic gradient helps the movement of sap from sugar sources to sugar sinks.
In vascular plants, the pressure flow hypothesis measures the bulk flow of sap that is transported by this tissue. The osmotic gradient of this tissue forms due to water flow from neighboring xylem.
This type of cell in phloem is primarily responsible for the transport of sucrose and other photosynthates. Along with companion cells, this elongated cell type originates from meristems.

answers: Dom Pedro II [prompt on Pedro]
Empire of Brazil [accept Federative Republic of Brazil or República Federativa do Brasil]
Ragamuffin War [accept Guerra dos Farrapos; accept Revolução Farroupilha] < Mitch McCullar | Non-European, Non-Commonwealth History >
parts: Name this emperor who abolished slavery in his country with the Golden Law.
Pedro II was the second and final ruler of this empire whose capital was seated in Rio de Janeiro.
The Piratini Republic was proclaimed by Antonio de Sousa Neto, triggering this uprising against Pedro II. Giuseppe Garibaldi led the navy for the Piratini Republic during this war.

answers: stele [or stela]
Great Mosque of Djenné [accept anything mentioning both Djenné and Great Mosque; prompt on Great Mosque; prompt on Mosque of Djenné by asking “Described by what adjective?”]
Republic of Zimbabwe [accept Great Zimbabwe] < Bryan Lu | Other Fine Arts >
parts: Name this type of monument, one of which was famously studied by Jean-François Champollion.

The wall of this building that faces Mecca is dominated by three boxy minarets, while every wall is decorated with rodier palm sticks. This mudbrick building exemplifies the traits of Malian architecture.

The Great Enclosure is an impressive system of walls at a “great” city in this country. Soapstone bird sculptures found in that city became a symbol of this southern African country with capital at Harare.

answers: Karen Horney (“horn-eye”) [accept Karen Horney née Danielson]
neurosis [accept word forms like neurotic]
Sigmund (Schlomo) Freud < Ethan Ashbrook | Social Science >
parts: Name this German psychoanalyst who stated that men had the subliminal desire for the ability to bear children like women in her theory of “womb envy.”
Horney developed a continuous theory of this type of disorder. This general class of disorders commonly results from stress, but without the radical loss with reality seen in psychosis.
Along with Alfred Adler, Horney developed many ideas that led to the psychoanalytic school against this psychologist. This cocaine-enthusiast wrote Interpretation of Dreams.

answers: Republic of North Macedonia [accept Republic of Macedonia]
Kingdom of eSwatini [accept Swaziland]
Myanmar [accept Burma] < Brad McLain / Sarod Nori | Current Events >
parts: In 2019, this country agreed to change its name in order to ease its entrance into NATO and the EU, ending a decades long feud with Greece.
In 2018 King Mswati III issued an order to change this country’s name as a rejection of the colonial name used by the British. This diarchic country is Africa’s last absolute monarchy.

This home country of Aung San Suu Kyi (ong san soo CHEE) has had to deal with ethnic violence in its Rakhine state. Military junta renamed this country in 1989 and moved this country’s capital from Yangon to Nay Pyi Taw (nay-PEE-dah).

answers: Robert Lowell [or Robert Traill Spence Lowell IV]
Boston [accept North of Boston]
“Patterns” < Mitch McCullar | Poetry >
parts: Name this poet. This author described an animal who “drops her ostrich tail, and will not scare” in his poem “Skunk Hour.”

Lowell’s poem “For the Union Dead” describes St. Gaudens’ statue in this city that commemorates Robert Gould Shaw and the colored 54th Regiment. Robert Frost wrote a collection titled for North of [this city].

Robert Lowell’s relative, Amy Lowell, wrote this poem about the speaker’s husband-to-be dying while “fighting with the Duke in Flanders” making her exclaim “Christ! What are [the title constructions] for?”

answers: commentaries on Peter Lombard’s Sentences [or commentaries on The Four Books of Sentences; or commentaries on Libri Quattuor Sententiarum; accept commentaries on Peter Lombard’s writings; accept logical equivalents for “commentaries” like “analyses”; prompt on commentaries (or similar stand alone responses) by asking “Commentaries on what work?”]
Peter Abelard [accept Peter Abaelardus]
St. Thomas Aquinas [prompt on St Thomas] < Brad McLain | Philosophy >
parts: Name these works; writing one of these works was required of Medieval scholars to earn a Master’s of Theology.
This thinker’s work, Sic et Non, served as an inspiration for Lombard’s Sentences. This scholastic thinker also described his castration in his autobiography History of My Calamities.

Like nearly every other Scholastic philosopher, this author of Summa Contra Gentiles wrote a commentary on Lombard’s Sentences. This theologian wrote five arguments for the existence of God in Summa Theologica.

answers: Walker Tariff of 1846 [prompt on Tariff of 1846]
James K. Polk [or James Knox Polk]
Trent Affair < Michael Etzkorn | US History >
parts: Name this 19th-century tariff named for the Secretary of the Treasury who suggested it. This tariff was implemented on the belief that decreased tariff rates would increase commerce between Great Britain and the United States.

This Democrat signed the Walker Tariff into law. This Tennessean, the only Speaker of the House elected president, resolved the Oregon Territory dispute and was president during the Mexican-American war.
Polk sent John Slidell to negotiate with Mexico over the Texas border. Slidell and James Murray Mason were later removed from a British ship by the USS San Jacinto in this Civil War-era incident.

answers: chaos [accept word forms like chaotic]
(Jules) Henri Poincaré
separation of variables [accept Fourier method] < Iain Carpenter | Other Science - Math >
parts: Nonlinear systems often exhibit this property. The double pendulum is the quintessential example of a system exhibiting this property due to the double pendulum’s sensitivity to initial conditions.
Chaotic systems that are defined by ordinary differential equations may still return to their starting point as a consequence of this French mathematician’s recurrence theorem.

First-order nonlinear differential equations are typically solved using this method which splits the derivative. This method is used to solve linear partial differential equations by making an ansatz that the solution is a product of single variable functions.

answers: The Custom of the Country
Edith Wharton [or Edith Newbold Jones]
Mattie Silver [accept either underlined name] < Mitch McCullar | Long-Form Fiction >
parts: Name this novel centering on Undine Spragg attempting to live a rich lifestyle. In this novel, Undine eventually marries Elmer Moffatt.
The Custom of the Country is by this author of The Age of Innocence and Ethan Frome.
Ethan Frome falls in love with this character, the cousin of his wife Zeena. This character is somewhat responsible for the cat breaking Zeena’s favorite pickle dish.

answers: geodesics [prompt on world lines]
world lines
space and time [accept spacetime; accept answers in either order] < Iain Carpenter | Physics >
parts: Name these constructs which generalizes the idea of a “straight line” to higher dimensions. Particles fall along these structures.
Geodesics are specific examples of these entities. Light cones bound these structures which map an object’s history on a Minkowski diagram.

On Minkowski diagrams, world lines are plotted with respect to these two quantities. These two concepts are fused together to create a four-dimensional manifold, whose curvature is related to gravity, in general relativity.

answers: Dietrich von Bern [prompt on von Bern]
dragons
dwarfs [or dwarves; accept a small child (on a technicality of some translations)] < Ethan Ashbrook | Mythology, Legends, and Stories >
parts: Name this legendary hero who fought his evil uncle Ermenrich, the ruler of Verona, at several encounters, such as the Battle of Ravenna.
Dietrich’s adventures through Germany involved fighting these creatures, one of which kills his partner Ortnit. Fafnir is an example of these fire-breathing serpents in Norse mythology.

Dietrich has numerous run-ins with these creatures, such as Laurin and Goldemar. In Ortnit’s title poem, Ortnit meets one of these creatures named Alberich, who can only be seen while wearing a magical ring.

answers: Thomas Cole
Kindred Spirits
Albert Bierstadt < Iain Carpenter | Painting and Sculpture >
parts: Name this artist whose painting Youth appears in his Voyage of Life Series. This Hudson River School artist painted the Course of Empire series and The Oxbow.
This 1849 Asher Durand painting shows Thomas Cole speaking to his friend William Cullen Bryant while surveying the Catskill mountains.
American westward expansion inspired this American-German member of the Hudson River School to paint works like Among the Sierra Nevada and The Rocky Mountains, Lander’s Peak.

answers: One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien Años de Soledad]
Gabriel (José de la Concordia) Garcia Marquez
eating competition [accept eating duel; accept logical equivalents of a competition to see who can eat the most (use your best judgement here)] < Michael Etzkorn / Mitch McCullar | Misc Literature >
parts: Name this novel. Towards the end of this novel, Amaranta gives birth to a pig-tailed child who is devoured by ants.
One Hundred Years of Solitude was written by this Colombian author of Love in the Time of Cholera.

In One Hundred Years of Solitude, Aureliano Segundo competes in this sort of competition with a woman nicknamed “The Elephant.” After 48 hours of battle, Aureliano Segundo asks to be taken to Fernanda before he falls unconscious as a result of this competition.

answers: Maurice Ravel
Gabriel Fauré
Dolly Suite < Dylan Bowman | Music >
parts: Name this composer who depicted a Spanish dance in his piece Bolero.
Ravel’s most famous teacher was this composer who, like his student, wrote a famous Pavane. His requiem ends with the movement In Paradisum.
This suite for piano four-hands by Fauré was written for Helene Bardac, with whom he had an affair. It opens with a famous Berceuse (bur-sooze) and its fourth movement is known as the Kitty waltz.

answers: Grotthuss mechanism [prompt on proton jumping]
superacids [do NOT accept or prompt on “acid”s]
water [or H2O] < Dylan Bowman / Michael Etzkorn | Chemistry >
parts: Name this mechanism proposed by a German scientist, where a proton diffuses through a network of hydrogen bonds.

This class of molecules experiences the Grotthuss mechanism due to the “naked” protons that they contain. This specific class of molecules are defined as having a Hammett function of less than 12 and usually contain a very stable fluorine atom willing to give up a hydrogen.

The Grotthuss mechanism most notably occurs in this molecule. This bent molecule is often called a “universal solvent” for its ability to break down substances by stabilizing them with hydrogen bonds.

answers: Publius Quinctilius Varus
Arminius [or Hermann; or Armin; or Irmin]
Ostrogoths [do NOT accept or prompt on “Goths”] < Sarod Nori | Classics, Britain, or Commonwealth >
parts: Augustus told this man to “give me back my legions” after the battle of Teutoburg Forest. This man, the first Roman governor of Germania, committed suicide after losing three legions in the battle.
This Germanic chieftain was victorious at the battle of Teutoburg Forest. His namesake “denkmal” is a statue of him located in Detmold in eastern North Rhine-Westphalia.
The battle of Teutoburg Forest hindered the Roman expansion into Germania and contributed to the rise of this Germanic tribe which split from the Visigoths.

answers: Czechoslovakia [accept Czech and Slovak Federative Republic; accept Fifth Czechoslovak Republic; accept Československá federativní republika; accept Česko-slovenská federatívna republika; accept Československo; do NOT accept or prompt on “Czechia” or “Czech Republic” or “Slovakia” or “Slovak Republic” or “Česká republika” or “Česko” or “Slovensko” or “Slovenská republika”]
Velvet Divorce [prompt on Velvet; prompt on Divorce; do NOT accept or prompt on “Velvet Revolution”]
Gustáv Husák < Sarod Nori | Continental Europe History >
parts: Name this former country. Alexander Dubcek promulgated the ideology of “socialism with a human face” during the Prague Spring in this country.
The dissolution of Czechoslovakia is sometimes known by this name in reference to a similarly named “Revolution” which saw the downfall of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia.
This last Communist president of Czechoslovakia was overthrown in the Velvet Revolution. His controversial policy of “normalization” saw a return to pre-Prague Spring conditions.

answers: Uncle Vanya [or Dyadya Vanya]
Anton Pavlovich Chekhov

Constanin Gavrilovich Treplev shooting himself [accept either “Constantin” or “Treplev” for the name of the character; accept general description of Treplev committing suicide or killing himself for “shooting himself”; prompt on the death of Treplev (or Constantin) with “How does he die?”] < Mitch McCullar | Drama >
parts: Name this play whose title character shoots at, but misses, Serebryakov after being told that the estate is going to be sold. Serebryakov’s wife, Yelena, is caught in a love triangle with this play’s title character and the nature-loving doctor Astrov.
Uncle Vanya was written by this Russian playwright of The Cherry Orchard and The Seagull.

In The Seagull, before this action occurs, several manuscripts are torn up by a character who says, “my mother would be distressed.” After this action occurs, Dorn informs Arkadina that one of his medicine bottles shattered.
